election_record.label: Pennsylvania 1816 Electoral College

overview.note: The Freeman's Journal and Philadelphia Mercantile Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) lists the name "James Maclay" in place of "James Meloy." November 22, 1816.
John Conard is also listed as John Conrad.
Thomas Patterson, Joseph Huston, John Harrison, and James Meloy were supported by both political factions.

Very few counties reported votes for individual electors. Most only reported the votes for the tickets as a whole. In these cases, the votes listed for the first candidates on each ticket represent the votes for the tickets as a whole.

The electors on the Republican Ticket (also referred to as the Caucus Ticket or the Assembly Ticket or the Legislative Ticket) were pledged to James Monroe. The electors on the Independent Ticket (also referred to as the Carlisle Ticket, Anti-Caucus Ticket, or the Federalist Ticket) were unpledged but would probably have supported either William Crawford or Rufus King.

"Yesterday the old tories, federalists, and old school men of this city and district voted what is called an 'Independent Electoral Ticket'." The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA). November 2, 1816.
Several newspaper sources report 25653 total votes for the Republican Ticket and 17588 total votes for the Independent Ticket.
The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA) reports 41840 total votes for James Meloy. November 21, 1816.

The Chronicle or Harrisburgh Visitor (Harrisburg, PA) reports 25674 total votes for John Mohlar, 25474 total votes for Abiel Fellows, 25498 total votes for Jacob Hostetter, 26359 total votes for Robert Clarke, 17561 total votes for Hugh Hart, 17474 total votes for Charles Thompson, and 17088 total votes for James Poe. December 2, 1816.
There were 25474 votes cast for Daniel Bussier and an additional 261 votes cast for David Bussier, although they were almost certainly intended for the same candidate and have been combined here.
There were 25178 votes cast for Jacob Hostetter and an additional 326 votes cast for John Hostetter, although they were almost certainly intended for the same candidate and have been combined here.
There were 25025 votes cast for David Marchand and an additional 422 votes cast for Daniel Marchand, although they were almost certainly intended for the same candidate and have been combined here.
There were 17534 votes cast for Peter Nagle, Sr. and an additional 23 votes cast for Peter Wagle, Sr., although they were almost certainly intended for the same candidate and have been combined here.
There were 17480 votes cast for Christian Brobst and an additional 23 votes cast for Charles Robst, although they were almost certainly intended for the same candidate and have been combined here.

sub_unit.name: Adams
sub_unit.note: "Adams gave 13 votes for a truly Federal ticket with Benjamin R. Morgan at its head." The American Telegraph (Brownsville, PA). December 4, 1816.

sub_unit.name: Armstrong
sub_unit.note: The Greensburgh and Indiana Register (Greensburg, PA) reports 69 votes for the Republican ticket in Armstrong County. November 9, 1816.

sub_unit.name: Beaver
sub_unit.note: Several sources which tally the votes from every county do not include the returns from Beaver, and thus report slightly lower totals for each Elector.
York Gazette and Public Advertiser (York, PA) from November 24, 1816 lists 189 votes for the Republican ticket in Beaver County.

sub_unit.name: Berks
sub_unit.note: The November 19th edition of The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA) and the December 4th edition of The American Telegraph (Brownsville, PA) both report 1543 votes for the Republican Ticket in Berks County.

sub_unit.name: Bucks
sub_unit.note: The Intelligencer, and Weekly Advertiser (Lancaster, PA) reports 1788 votes for the Republican Ticket and 1948 votes for the Independent Ticket in Bucks County. November 9, 1816.

sub_unit.name: Cambria
sub_unit.note: The Independent Electors cast their votes for the King/Howard ticket. History of Cambria County, 104.
The Berks and Schuylkill Journal (Reading, PA) reports 57 votes for the Republican Ticket in Cambria County. November 23, 1816.

sub_unit.name: Clearfield
sub_unit.note: The votes cast in Clearfield County are included in the Centre County returns.

sub_unit.name: Chester
sub_unit.note: "Chester gave 7 votes for a truly Federal ticket with James Ross at its head." The American Telegraph (Brownsville, PA). December 4, 1816.

sub_unit.name: Cumberland
sub_unit.note: The American Volunteer (Carlisle, PA) provides early township totals for Cumberland County. These returns total 1256 votes for the Democratic Ticket. November 7, 1816.
"From what we can learn, the Federalist alone, exerted themselves in favor of the independent ticket, and acted with a deal of consistency." The American Volunteer (Carlisle, PA). November 7, 1816.
The American Telegraph (Brownsville, PA) reports 527 votes for the Independent Ticket in Cumberland County. December 4, 1816.

sub_unit.name: Delaware
sub_unit.note: "Delaware gave an average vote of two for a truly Federal ticket with Isaac Darlington as the head who had 7 votes." The American Telegraph (Brownsville, PA). December 4, 1816.
The Intelligencer, and Weekly Advertiser (Lancaster, PA) reports 347 votes for the Republican Ticket in Delaware County. November 9, 1816.

sub_unit.name: Franklin
sub_unit.note: The Democratic Republican and Pennsylvania Advertiser (Chambersburg, PA) provides early individual township returns of 810 votes for the Republican Ticket and 79 votes for the Independent Ticket in Franklin County. November 4, 1816.

sub_unit.name: Huntingdon
sub_unit.note: The American Telegraph (Brownsville, PA) reports 444 votes for the Republican Ticket in Huntingdon County. December 4, 1816.

sub_unit.name: Indiana
sub_unit.note: The Greensburgh and Indiana Register (Greensburg, PA) reports 75 votes for the Republican ticket in Indiana County. November 9, 1816.
The Pittsburgh Mercury (Pittsburgh, PA) reports 145 votes for the Independent Ticket in Indiana County. November 30, 1816.

sub_unit.name: Jefferson
sub_unit.note: The votes cast in Jefferson County are included in the Indiana County returns.

sub_unit.name: Mount Joy
sub_unit.note: The Intelligencer, and Weekly Advertiser (Lancaster, PA) refers to Mount Joy Township as "Elizabeth." November 9, 1816.

sub_unit.name: Rapho
sub_unit.note: The Intelligencer, and Weekly Advertiser (Lancaster, PA) refers to Rapho Township as "Manheim." November 9, 1816.

sub_unit.name: McKean
sub_unit.note: The votes cast in McKean County are included in the Lycoming County returns.

sub_unit.name: Potter
sub_unit.note: The votes cast in Potter County are included in the Lycoming County returns.

sub_unit.name: Mercer
sub_unit.note: The Northumberl. Republicaner, und Northumberland, Union und Columbia Counties Adverteiser (Sunbury, PA) reports 130 votes for the Republican ticket in Mercer County. November 29, 1816.

sub_unit.name: Montgomery
sub_unit.note: The Intelligencer, and Weekly Advertiser (Lancaster, PA) reports 1218 votes for the Independent Ticket in Montgomery County. November 9, 1816.
The American Telegraph (Brownsville, PA) reports 1210 votes for the Independent Ticket in Montgomery County. December 4, 1816.

sub_unit.name: Northumberland
sub_unit.note: "At the November election, Monroe and Tompkins received six hundred and one votes, against one hundred and two for the opposition or Independent Republican ticket, on which were the names of Andrew Gregg, Christian Brobst, Daniel Montgomery, and others, as electors." Annals of Buffalo Valley, by John Blair Linn. Heritage Books, 1877. 434.

The Northumberl. Republicaner, und Northumberland, Union und Columbia Counties Adverteiser (Sunbury, PA) specifies 506 votes for the James Monroe ticket and 157 votes for the DeWitt Clinton ticket in Northumberland County. November 8, 1816.

sub_unit.name: Philadelphia
sub_unit.note: The Pennsylvania Republican (Harrisburg, PA) reports 1148 votes for the Republican Ticket in Philadelphia City. November 19, 1816.

The Freeman's Journal and Philadelphia Mercantile Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) reports 1139 votes for the New School Republican Ticket and 2139 votes for the Old School Republican Ticket in Philadelphia City. November 4, 1816.

sub_unit.name: Philadelphia
sub_unit.note: Relf's Philadelphia Gazette. And Daily Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) and The Democratic Press, both from November 2, 1816, report 1701 votes for the Republican Ticket and 1973 votes for the Independent Ticket in Philadelphia County and include individual tornship returns.

The Freeman's Journal and Philadelphia Mercantile Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) reports 1701 votes for the New School Republican Ticket and 1973 votes for the Old School Republican Ticket in Philadelphia County and includes individual township returns. November 4, 1816.

sub_unit.name: Passyunk
sub_unit.note: Poulson's American Daily Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) reports 53 votes for the Republican Ticket in Passyunk Township.

sub_unit.name: Schuylkill
sub_unit.note: The American Telegraph (Brownsville, PA) reports 350 votes for the Republican Ticket in Schuylkill County. December 4, 1816.

sub_unit.name: Warren
sub_unit.note: The votes cast in Warren County are included in the Venango County returns.

sub_unit.name: Washington
sub_unit.note: The Reporter (Washington, PA) reports 448 votes for the Harrisburg Caucus Ticket and 103 votes for the Carlisle Caucus Ticket in Washington County. November 11, 1816.

sub_unit.name: Wayne
sub_unit.note: The Northumberl. Republicaner, und Northumberland, Union und Columbia Counties Adverteiser (Sunbury, PA) reports 92 votes for the Republican ticket in Wayne County. November 29, 1816.

sub_unit.name: Westmoreland
sub_unit.note: The Greensburgh Gazette (Greensburg, PA) reports 413 votes for the Republican Ticket and 306 votes for the Independent Ticket in Westmoreland County. November 9, 1816.

sub_unit.name: York
sub_unit.note: "Jacob Hostetter, who stood highest on the Monroe Ticket has 978 votes, and Andrew Gregg who is one of the highest on the Independent Carlisle Caucus Ticket, has 319." York Gazette and Public Advertiser (York, PA). November 7, 1816.
Most newspaper sources report 980 votes for the Republican Ticket and 318 votes for the Independent Ticket in York County.
